sub_title: PhD, Senior Scientist at Philips Research, SAFe certified Product Owner/Manager & Scrum Master. Skilled in Medical image processing & reconstruction, mathematical optimization methods, data analysis, ML/AI, SIMD software
summary:
Alfonso Agatino Isola was born in Catania (Italy) on February 4, 1978.

He received his M.Sc. degree in Computer Engineering from the University of Catania, in 2006, for his work on methodologies and instruments for the characterization of the Parkinson disease.  

From June 2006 till February 2007, he worked as Computer Science Researcher for the Thales Nederland B.V. in Hengelo (Netherlands).

From March 2007 till February 2010, he worked towards his Ph.D. degree at Philips Research - Hamburg and in cooperation with the Erasmus MC, University Medical Center Rotterdam. His research interests included motion-compensated iterative reconstruction algorithms, motion estimation methodologies for cardiac CT, elastic image registration, and parametric assessment of myocardial perfusion. 

He received his Ph.D. degree from the Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam, in 2010, for his dissertation entitled  "Motion Compensated Iterative Reconstruction for Cardiac X-ray Tomography" (available at: http://hdl.handle.net/1765/19823).

From March till September 2010, he worked as Research Scientist at Philips Research - Hamburg. He studied and investigated novel image reconstruction methods for Cardiac C-arm X-ray.

From October 2010 till March 2013, he worked as Research Scientist at Philips Research - Eindhoven. He studied novel medical imaging solutions.

Since April 2013, he is working as Senior Scientist at Philips Research - Eindhoven. His research interests lie in the field of numerical optimization for radiation and thermal ablation treatment planning (e.g. Pinnacle Evolution TPS, DynaCAD Urology ablation planning, etc.), and in the field of AI and data science for cardiac diagnostic solutions (e.g. IntelliSpace Portal 12).

Reviewer for "Medical Physics", "Physics in Medicine and Biology", and "Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine".

Specialties: RF/MW/Cryo thermal ablation, LDR/HDR brachytherapy and EBRT planning, cardiac CT imaging, cardiac motion correction, myocardial perfusion, numerical optimization, medical physics, image processing, image reconstruction, image registration, AI, machine learning, data science, SIMD vectorized software (SSE,AVX), C, C++, C#, Python, Matlab.

Licenses & certifications: Scaled Agile SAFe® 5 Scrum Master and Product Owner/Product Manager.

treasury_media.title: DynaCAD_Urology_whitepaper.pdf
treasury_media.description: The Ablation Planning option for DynaCAD Urology helps you prepare for ablation procedures by presenting the target regions along with critical structures identified in MR, and previously acquired biopsy data. Furthermore, DynaCAD Urology combines your clinical objectives with information about your ablation devices and applicators for automatic ablation plan computation.

profile_positions.location: Eindhoven Area, High Tech Campus, Netherlands
profile_positions.description: My current research interests lie in the fields of image processing, numerical optimization and AI methodologies for Laser/RF/Microwave/Cryo thermal ablation, LDR/HDR brachytherapy, external beam radiation treatment planning (e.g. Pinnacle Evolution TPS, DynaCAD Urology ablation planning, etc), and for cardiac diagnostic solutions (e.g. IntelliSpace Portal 12).
profile_positions.title: Senior Scientist

profile_positions.location: Eindhoven Area, High Tech Campus, Netherlands
profile_positions.description: My research interests lay in the field of novel medical imaging solutions.
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description: Within this role I was studying and investigating novel image reconstruction methods for Cardiac C-arm X-ray.
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description: Starting from March 2007, I moved to the Philips Research of Hamburg. Within this new role inside the Research Sector Medical Imaging Systems, I was studying and investigating on a new project that aimed at developing a three-dimensional method to reconstruct moving objects from cone-beam X-ray projections using an iterative reconstruction algorithm and a given motion vector field (MVF). This approach was successfully applied to perform "motion artefact" free cardiac CT image reconstructions. This PhD project was based on a strong cooperation between industrial research, university groups, and clinical partners. I benefited from an extensive european research network, offering cooperation with the Biomedical Imaging Group of my host university "Erasmus Medical Center University of Rotterdam" and three clinical partners (Hamburg, Aachen, Stockholm).
profile_positions.title: PhD Student

company.name: Erasmus MC - University Medical Center Rotterdam

profile_positions.description:
Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam, The Netherlands
PhD thesis: "Motion compensated iterative reconstruction for cardiac X-ray tomography"
Promotor: Prof. dr. Wiro Niessen (Erasmus MC, Rotterdam)
Copromotor: dr. Michael Graß (Philips Research, Hamburg)
PhD Defense: 18th June 2010.
profile_positions.title: External PhD Student

profile_positions.description:
Computer Science Researcher, THALES NEDERLAND B.V., Surface Radar-TC-TU-Processing (Hengelo, The Netherlands)

During these 9 months at TNL B.V. I’ve been involved into three main set of activities, (1) Investigation and implementation of one MPI middleware for inter-process communications among Radar applications, (2) Investigation and implementation of one Data Distribution Service middleware for inter-process communications among Radar applications, and (3) working on the parallelization of some codes by using the Intel Threading Building Blocks. Furthermore, I’ve worked on several other topics related to THALES Radar processes communications, e.g. the SPLICE2 middleware and the PHANTOM infraware.
profile_positions.title: Computer Science Researcher
